articles.headline: Pelosi Turns to Arm Twisting After Resounding Vote Leaves Her Just Short of Speakership
articles.snippet: The 203-to-32 vote showed Nancy Pelosi had most Democrats behind her, but the result kept alive the threat of a messy intraparty feud.
articles.abstract: The 203-to-32 vote showed Nancy Pelosi had most Democrats behind her, but the result kept alive the threat of a messy intraparty feud.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Nancy Pelosi overwhelmingly won the Democratic nomination on Wednesday to be speaker when the new Congress convenes in January, but the defection of 32 Democrats signaled that she could still face a divisive fight to lead the House just as the party assumes control.

articles.headline: Two Words From Fed Chairman Jerome Powell Sent Markets Soaring
articles.snippet: Investors interpreted comments by Mr. Powell, the Federal Reserve chairman, as an indication that the central bank may be less inclined to continue raising interest rates.
articles.abstract: Investors interpreted comments by Mr. Powell, the Federal Reserve chairman, as an indication that the central bank may be less inclined to continue raising interest rates.
articles.lead_paragraph: With just two words on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve’s chairman sent stocks surging by raising hopes that the central bank might be closer to ending its push to drive up interest rates.

articles.headline: Senators, Furious Over Khashoggi Killing, Spurn President on War in Yemen
articles.snippet: A vote to limit U.S. military support in Yemen showed widespread disapproval of President Trump’s embrace of Saudi Arabia after the killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi.
articles.abstract: A vote to limit U.S. military support in Yemen showed widespread disapproval of President Trump’s embrace of Saudi Arabia after the killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Furious over being denied a C.I.A. briefing on the killing of a Saudi journalist, senators from both parties spurned the Trump administration on Wednesday with a stinging vote to consider ending American military support for the Saudi-backed war in Yemen.
articles.byline: By Gardiner Harris, Eric Schmitt, Helene Cooper and Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: G.M., Not Trump, Is the Real Villain to Some Ohio Factory Workers
articles.snippet: In a region where the president vowed that manufacturing jobs were coming back, the idling of a Chevrolet plant and its 1,600 workers is a major blow.
articles.abstract: In a region where the president vowed that manufacturing jobs were coming back, the idling of a Chevrolet plant and its 1,600 workers is a major blow.
articles.lead_paragraph: LORDSTOWN, Ohio — After an election campaign in which he had pledged a manufacturing renaissance, President Trump came to this once-thriving industrial region of northeastern Ohio last year and all but waved a mission-accomplished flag.

articles.headline: ‘If Bobbie Talks, I’m Finished’: How Les Moonves Tried to Silence an Accuser
articles.snippet: A trove of text messages details a plan by Mr. Moonves and a faded Hollywood manager to bury a sexual assault allegation. Instead, the scheme helped sink the CBS chief, and may cost him $120 million.
articles.abstract: A trove of text messages details a plan by Mr. Moonves and a faded Hollywood manager to bury a sexual assault allegation. Instead, the scheme helped sink the CBS chief, and may cost him $120 million.
articles.lead_paragraph: Saturday, April 28, 2018, was Marv Dauer’s 75th birthday. It was also going to be his comeback.
articles.byline: By James B. Stewart, Rachel Abrams and Ellen Gabler

articles.headline: No Bed, No Breakfast, but 4-Star Gunfire. Welcome to a War Hostel.
articles.snippet: A Sarajevo hostel recreating the 1990s wartime experience falls under a growing global niche of “dark tourism.” There are no beds, and the sound of gunfire fills the rooms, but there is Wi-Fi.
articles.abstract: A Sarajevo hostel recreating the 1990s wartime experience falls under a growing global niche of “dark tourism.” There are no beds, and the sound of gunfire fills the rooms, but there is Wi-Fi.
articles.lead_paragraph: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina — Arijan Kurbasic, the manager of the War Hostel Sarajevo in the Bosnian capital, knows that his idea of hospitality is not to everyone’s taste and is ready to relax the house rules a bit.

articles.headline: Trump Talks of Pardon for Manafort and Escalates Attacks on Russia Inquiry
articles.snippet: “Why would I take it off the table?” the president said of a pardon for Paul Manafort, who he said had been treated poorly by prosecutors for the special counsel.
articles.abstract: “Why would I take it off the table?” the president said of a pardon for Paul Manafort, who he said had been treated poorly by prosecutors for the special counsel.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Escalating his attacks on the special counsel investigation, President Trump said on Wednesday that a presidential pardon for his former campaign chairman Paul Manafort is “not off the table,” casting him and other subjects of the inquiry as victims of prosecutorial abuse.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere and Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: After a Hiatus, China Accelerates Cyberspying Efforts to Obtain U.S. Technology
articles.snippet: China’s practice of breaking into American computers has become a core grievance of the Trump administration as leaders of the two nations prepare to meet.
articles.abstract: China’s practice of breaking into American computers has become a core grievance of the Trump administration as leaders of the two nations prepare to meet.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Three years ago, President Barack Obama struck a deal with China that few thought was possible: President Xi Jinping agreed to end his nation’s yearslong practice of breaking into the computer systems of American companies, military contractors and government agencies to obtain designs, technology and corporate secrets, usually on behalf of China’s state-owned firms.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: A Farmer’s Tough Year on the Trade War’s Kansas Front
articles.snippet: From planning to harvest, the grain belt’s rhythms and prospects have been disrupted by the government’s tariff battle with China.
articles.abstract: From planning to harvest, the grain belt’s rhythms and prospects have been disrupted by the government’s tariff battle with China.
articles.lead_paragraph: Justin Knopf finished harvesting soybeans as November’s first snowflakes started falling on his fields in Gypsum, Kan. Then he did what thousands of farmers throughout the grain belt are doing: He got an application for some of the $12 billion in federal emergency relief intended to blunt the economic fallout from President Trump’s trade policy brinkmanship.

articles.headline: Deutsche Bank Offices Are Searched in Money Laundering Investigation
articles.snippet: The company’s headquarters in Frankfurt were raided as part of an inquiry related to the so-called Panama Papers.
articles.abstract: The company’s headquarters in Frankfurt were raided as part of an inquiry related to the so-called Panama Papers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Deutsche Bank’s efforts to escape a history of scandal, wrongdoing and mismanagement suffered a serious setback Thursday after the German police raided its headquarters in Frankfurt as part of an investigation into whether the lender helped criminals launder money through offshore tax havens.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing, Melissa Eddy and Amie Tsang

articles.headline: Falling Oil Prices May Make Trump Happy but They Pose Risks for U.S.
articles.snippet: While falling prices help consumers, another big decline of the kind the president is seeking could hurt the economy in oil-producing states like Texas.
articles.abstract: While falling prices help consumers, another big decline of the kind the president is seeking could hurt the economy in oil-producing states like Texas.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Oil prices have plunged by about 25 percent in the last month while the cost of gasoline has tumbled to as little as $2 a gallon in several states. President Trump is pushing for even lower prices, calling it “a big Tax Cut for America and the World.”
